conclusion: Consider principles of shadow formation and effects of light source position.
Light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows directly below them.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are formed directly beneath the objects.
When the light source moves forward, it will change the angle of light relative to the objects.
Shadows will shift position and change in size based on the new angle of light.
As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift backward, away from the light source.
Shadows will appear to move in the opposite direction of the light source's movement.
The size of the shadows will increase as the light source moves forward.
The angle of light becomes more oblique, causing the shadows to stretch out.
Shadow A (Sphere) will shift backward and become larger and more elongated.
Shadow B (Cylinder) will shift backward and become larger and more elongated.
Shadow C (Cake) will shift backward and become larger and more elongated.
Shadow D (Waffle) will shift backward and become larger and more elongated.
If the light source moves forward, above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will shift backward and become larger and more elongated.
